Award.AwardTitle: An Integrative Study of the Genetic and Molecular Basis of Human Brain Evolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A hallmark of human evolution is the exceptional size and complexity of our brains. Previous genetic studies have revealed that genes that are specific to human brains show particular evolutionary characteristics both at the DNA sequence and at the level of gene expression. However, the causes of such molecular changes are not known. The proposed research will investigate the molecular basis of human brain evolution using an integrative approach of genetic, epigenetic, and gene expression analyses. A central hypothesis of the proposed research is that epigenetic changes, in particular changes of DNA methylation, have facilitated the evolution of human brains. DNA methylation is a key epigenetic modification of genomic DNA that mediates information transfer between the genotype and phenotypes.

The objectives of this study are first to generate DNA methylation maps of multiple humans, chimpanzees, macaques and marmosets. This novel data will be then integrated with gene expression maps of the same samples. By doing so, we can answer 1) whether DNA methylation levels exhibit a particular evolutionary trend among the primate brains examined, 2) if DNA methylation changes are correlated with gene expression changes in a species-specific manner, and 3) whether such changes are more pronounced for genes that are pertinent for the brain size and complexity. Consequently, the proposed research will elucidate the evolutionary changes and the functional consequences of DNA methylation in human brains.

The proposed research is integrative in nature and will contribute to training undergraduate and graduate students in diverse disciplines including primate evolution, phylogenetics, molecular anthropology, and comparative genomics. The proposed research is integrated with an institutional outreach program, Georgia Industrial Fellowship for Teachers, to provide training for high school students and teachers in the metro Atlanta area. As a central activity of the proposed research, an open access website harboring comprehensive information on genomic, epigenomic and expression differences of the study species will be developed. Finally, the proposed research will increase our understanding of the genetic and molecular basis of the evolution of human brains, which is one of the most fascinating aspects of human evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fascinating feature that sets humans apart from other closely related species is the human brain. Previous comparative studies have shown that the human brain has undergone remarkable degrees of evolution, including a dramatic enlargement (encephalization) as well as notable changes of macro- and micro- substructures. At the molecular level, gene expression and protein abundance also show substantial difference between human brains and the brains of other non-human apes.

 

In contrast to these findings, sequence analyses of genes that are specifically expressed in brains (referred to as ‘brain-specific’ genes) painted a different picture. Studies found that brain-specific genes were more conserved than other genes at the sequence level. The current project was motivated by these conflicting observations. Specifically, we hypothesized that ‘epigenetic’ mechanisms, which refer to chemical modifications of genomic DNA, may have changed between the brains of humans and those of non-human primates, and that such epigenetic changes have contributed to the evolution of human brains. Epigenetic changes can occur with no or minimal sequence changes, yet could lead to drastic gene expression differences. Thus, our hypothesis can reconcile the aforementioned conflicting observations.

 

To test this hypothesis, we examined DNA methylation patterns of brains from several humans, chimpanzees, and rhesus macaques. Specifically, we generated whole genome DNA methylation maps using bisulfite-sequencing methods. These maps were the first of its kind to be produced from human and non-human primate brains. These methylation maps allowed us to examine which positions of the human genome have changed their brain DNA methylation patterns since the divergence of humans and chimpanzees. We then selected 38 such regions (named human-specific differentially methylated regions, or human-specific DMRs) and tested their methylation in an independent panel of 40 human and non-human primate individuals, including chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans, gibbons, rhesus macaques, and crab-eating macaques. Most of these regions (36 out of 38) were validated in all species, providing strong support for our findings.

 

To infer the functional role of DNA methylation changes, we then asked what kind of genomic regions were particularly prone to such changes during human evolution. We found that genomic regions that are near genes and presumably act as regulatory sequences have preferentially changed their DNA methylation patterns. These results imply that human specific epigenetic changes have contributed to human-specific patterns of gene expression, as we hypothesized. In addition, we found many human-specific DMRs in regions without any currently presumed function. Further investigation revealed that such DMRs contained other epigenetic marks that are often found in regulatory regions. Furthermore, many of them in fact had a transcript starting within them. Based on these observations, we hypothesize that these un-annotated DMRs may be new regulatory regions in the human brain.

 

In the course of our work, we generated a large number of non-coding genomic molecular markers from diverse New World monkeys. Our goal is to use these markers to aid classification of New World monkeys and prioritize which species to analyze in DNA methylation studies. We also demonstrated the utilities of these markers in phylogeographic studies. The newly generated DNA methylation data from humans and non-human primate species also allowed us to study several other questions regarding DNA methylation and evolution. For example, we showed that the evolutionary age of duplicated genes is related to how much DNA methylation divergence occurs between duplicate genes, and linked this finding to balancing gene expression dosage of duplicated genes. We also found that some genes are devoid of DNA methylation within their coding sequences, and that those genes have specific evolutionary histories and disease associations.

 

This project provided rich educational opportunities across several different platforms. Several PhD students, MS students, undergraduate students and postdoctoral scientists were directly involved in this research, thus trained in human brain evolution, epigenetics and anthropology. The topics and findings of this proposed research were incorporated into the PI’s courses, Molecular Evolution and Introductory Evolutionary Biology. In addition, the PI developed a new undergraduate course based on many related topics:  ‘Neurogenomics’, to be offered for the first time in Spring 2018. The results of the current research was also disseminated in the broader scientific community by several publications, as well as presentations in multiple conferences and invited lectures, by the PI as well as by several trainees. The whole genome DNA methylation data generated during the course of the research have been deposited to public databases, and will serve as a rich trove of information that will continue to reveal deeper insights into human brain evolution.
